title: How to Write an Email to a Friend

steps.title: Find your friend’s email address.
steps.content: Find your friend’s email address. Before you start your email, make sure that you have the correct email address for your friend. If you’ve sent an email to them in the past, you can find their email in your email contacts . Otherwise, you can ask another friend. [1] X Research source Type their email address into the box labeled “To.”

steps.title: Choose a subject that summarizes your email.
steps.content: Choose a subject that summarizes your email. The subject box is located below the “To” box and labeled “Subject.” Summarize your email in a few words here so your friend knows what to expect. [2] X Research source If you’re just writing to say hello, your subject line could be as simple as “Hi!” If you’re writing to invite your friend to your birthday party , you could make the subject, “Invitation to my birthday party.”

steps.title: Open with a greeting.
steps.content: Open with a greeting. Start your email with a greeting, followed by the person’s name and a comma. Since this is an email to a friend, you can say something casual like “hi,” “hey,” or “hello.” [3] X Trustworthy Source University of North Carolina Writing Center UNC's on-campus and online instructional service that provides assistance to students, faculty, and others during the writing process Go to source ”Hi Kate,” is an example of a basic greeting.

steps.title: Ask them how they’re doing.
steps.content: Ask them how they’re doing. Skip a line, and ask a question like, “How are you doing?” or make a statement like, “I hope you’re doing well.” This shows your friend you care about them. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tell them why you’re writing.
steps.content: Tell them why you’re writing. Maybe you’re writing to see how their vacation is going, or to check in after an illness. Either way, start off your email by stating your purpose for writing. Say something like, “I heard you had the flu , and I wanted to see how you’re doing.”

steps.title: Tell them what you want to say in a few paragraphs.
steps.content: Tell them what you want to say in a few paragraphs. Now that you’ve finished your introduction, it’s time to get down everything you want to tell your friend. Break up big chunks of text into paragraphs of three or four sentences to make your email easier to read.

steps.title: Avoid all caps text as much as possible.
steps.content: Avoid all caps text as much as possible. You may want to use all caps to show your excitement, but it can seem like you’re yelling. Instead, use asterisks or bold your text to highlight the important parts. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Ask questions every so often.
steps.content: Ask questions every so often. Ask questions related to what you’re saying. This shows your friend that you’re interested in their opinion, too. [6] X Research source If you’re talking about your trip to the beach, you could throw in a question like, “Have you been down to the beach yet this summer? If not, you should totally go.”

steps.title: Apologize for the lack of contact.
steps.content: Apologize for the lack of contact. It’s normal for people to fall out of touch, but you should still offer an apology to start off on the right foot. [7] X Research source You could say, “I’m sorry it’s been so long since we talked. I’ve been really busy.”

steps.title: Update them on your life and ask about theirs.
steps.content: Update them on your life and ask about theirs. Since you haven’t talked in a while, you probably have a lot to catch up on. Tell your friend about any exciting developments in your life, and ask what’s new with them. [8] X Research source You could say, “Since we last talked, I started dating someone. It’s been going great. Have you started dating anyone?”

steps.title: Talk about common interests.
steps.content: Talk about common interests. Spend a little time talking about the things you both love. If you’re avid soccer fans, use a few lines to recap your favorite team’s most recent game. Don’t forget to ask for their opinion , too. [9] X Research source Say something like, “That game the other week was insane! What did you think about the final goal?”

steps.title: Add an invite or request near the end of the email, if you want.
steps.content: Add an invite or request near the end of the email, if you want. If you want to invite your friend to hang out soon or attend your party, now’s the time to let them know. [10] X Trustworthy Source University of North Carolina Writing Center UNC's on-campus and online instructional service that provides assistance to students, faculty, and others during the writing process Go to source You might say, “I’m having a baby shower next Tuesday evening. Do you think you can make it?

steps.title: Experiment with different fonts and text colors.
steps.content: Experiment with different fonts and text colors. Explore the formatting bar, which is a row of icons located at the top or bottom of your window, to check out different font and text color options. If your email is about a serious subject, it’s best to stick with plain black text in a basic font. [11] X Research source If your friend has a different email server, some fonts may not show up. Arial, Times, Verdana, Trebuchet, and Geneva are usually safe. [12] X Research source Try not to go overboard with different fonts and colors. Your text should still be easy to read.

steps.title: Add emojis if appropriate.
steps.content: Add emojis if appropriate. If you’re writing a fun email to a good friend, a few cute emojis here and there could make your email extra friendly. However, if you’re writing an email about a more serious topic, you should steer clear of emojis. They’ll make your email seem too lighthearted. Be careful not to use too many emojis--it can be distracting.

steps.title: Finish up by wishing them well.
steps.content: Finish up by wishing them well. Send your friend kind wishes, let them know if you’d like them to write back, and tell them you hope to see them soon. [13] X Research source You might say, “I hope that you have a great week. I can’t wait to hear from you!”

steps.title: Close and sign your email.
steps.content: Close and sign your email. End your email with a closing, like “best wishes,” “talk to you soon,” or “love.” Then, skip a couple lines and type your name.

steps.title: Attach images if you need to.
steps.content: Attach images if you need to. Click the “insert photo” button, which usually looks like a picture or camera icon. It’ll be next to all the other formatting buttons. Then, you can pick photos from your computer to upload. If you’re writing an email telling a friend about your new dog, it might be a good idea to send along a picture of the pup! Try to only attach a few photos. If you attach too many, your email may end up in your friend’s spam folder. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Proofread your email.
steps.content: Proofread your email. When you’ve finished your email, read through it once or twice to look for spelling and grammar mistakes. A mistake-free email will be easier for your friend to read. If you’re a kid, get a trusted adult to help you out. [15] X Research source Double check to make sure you have the right email address for your friend, too.

steps.title: Press send.
steps.content: Press send. When your email is ready to go, click the button at the bottom of your email that says “send.” All done!
